Separating Anatolia and Thrace are the Sea of Marmara and the Turkish Straits (the Bosporus and the Dardanelles), which are commonly reckoned to delineate the border between Asia and Europe, thereby making Turkey transcontinental. The territory of Turkey is subdivided into 81 provinces for administrative purposes. The provinces are organized into 7 regions for census purposes; however, they do not represent an administrative structure. Each province is divided into districts, for a total of 923 districts.

A country in Central Asia. It is bordered by Afghanistan to the southeast, Iran to the southwest, Uzbekistan to the northeast, Kazakhstan to the northwest, and the Caspian Sea to the west. It was a constituent republic of the Soviet Union, the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic. Turkmenistan is divided into five provinces or welayatlar (singular - welayat) and one independent city.

A British Overseas Territory consisting of two groups of tropical islands in the West Indies. The Turks and Caicos Islands are divided into six administrative districts (two in the Turks Islands and four in the Caicos Islands.
A Polynesian island nation located in the Pacific Ocean midway between Hawaii and Australia.

A federal constitutional republic comprising fifty states and a federal district. The country is situated mostly in central North America, where its forty-eight contiguous states and Washington, DC, the capital district, lie between the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, bordered by Canada to the north and Mexico to the south. The State of Alaska is in the northwest of the continent, with Canada to its east and Russia to the west across the Bering Strait, and the State of Hawaii is in the mid-Pacific. The United States also possesses several territories, or insular areas, that are scattered around the Caribbean and Pacific. The states are divided into smaller administrative regions, called counties in most states, exceptions being Alaska (parts of the state are organized into subdivisions called boroughs; the rest of the state's territory that is not included in any borough is divided into "census areas"), and Louisiana (which is divided into county-equivalents that are called parishes). There are also independent cities which are within particular states but not part of any particular county or consolidated city-counties. Another type of organization is where the city and county are unified and function as an independent city. There are thirty-nine independent cities in Virginia and other independent cities or city-counties are San Francisco, California, Baltimore, Maryland, St. Louis, Missouri, Denver, Colorado and Carson City, Nevada. Counties can include a number of cities, towns, villages, or hamlets, or sometimes just a part of a city. Counties have varying degrees of political and legal significance, but they are always administrative divisions of the state. Counties in many states are further subdivided into townships, which, by definition, are administrative divisions of a county. In some states, such as Michigan, a township can file a charter with the state government, making itself into a "charter township", which is a type of mixed municipal and township status (giving the township some of the rights of a city without all of the responsibilities), much in the way a metropolitan municipality is a mixed municipality and county.

A landlocked country in East Africa, bordered on the east by Kenya, the north by Sudan, on the west by the Democratic Republic of the Congo, on the southwest by Rwanda, and on the south by Tanzania. The southern part of the country includes a substantial portion of Lake Victoria, within which it shares borders with Kenya and Tanzania. Uganda is divided into 80 districts, spread across four administrative regions: Northern, Eastern, Central and Western. The districts are subdivided into counties.

A country in Eastern Europe. It borders Russia to the east, Belarus to the north, Poland, Slovakia and Hungary to the west, Romania and Moldova to the southwest, and the Black Sea and Sea of Azov to the south. Ukraine is subdivided into twenty-four oblasts (provinces) and one autonomous republic (avtonomna respublika), Crimea. Additionally, the cities of Kiev, the capital, and Sevastopol, both have a special legal status. The 24 oblasts and Crimea are subdivided into 490 raions (districts), or second-level administrative units.

A Middle Eastern federation of seven states situated in the southeast of the Arabian Peninsula in Southwest Asia on the Persian Gulf, bordering Oman and Saudi Arabia. The seven states, termed emirates, are Abu Dhabi, Ajman, Dubai, Fujairah, Ras al-Khaimah, Sharjah, and Umm al-Quwain.

A sovereign island country located off the northwestern coast of mainland Europe comprising of the four constituent countries; England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It comprises the island of Great Britain, the northeast part of the island of Ireland and many small islands. Apart from Northern Ireland the UK is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean, the North Sea, the English Channel and the Irish Sea. The largest island, Great Britain, is linked to France by the Channel Tunnel.

A country located in the southeastern part of South America. It is bordered by Brazil to the north, by Argentina across the bank of both the Uruguay River to the west and the estuary of Rio de la Plata to the southwest, and the South Atlantic Ocean to the southeast. Uraguay consists of 19 departments (departamentos, singular - departamento).

A doubly landlocked country in Central Asia, formerly part of the Soviet Union. It shares borders with Kazakhstan to the west and to the north, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan to the east, and Afghanistan and Turkmenistan to the south. Uzbekistan is divided into twelve provinces (viloyatlar) one autonomous republic (respublika and one independent city (shahar).

An island country located in the South Pacific Ocean. The archipelago, which is of volcanic origin, is 1,750 kilometres (1,090 mi) east of northern Australia, 540 kilometres (340 mi) northeast of New Caledonia, east of New Guinea, southeast of the Solomon Islands, and west of Fiji.

A country on the northern coast of South America. The country comprises a continental mainland and numerous islands located off the Venezuelan coastline in the Caribbean Sea. The Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela possesses borders with Guyana to the east, Brazil to the south, and Colombia to the west. Trinidad and Tobago, Grenada, St. Lucia, Barbados, Curacao, Bonaire, Aruba, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and the Leeward Antilles lie just north, off the Venezuelan coast. Venezuela is divided into twenty-three states (Estados), a capital district (distrito capital) corresponding to the city of Caracas, the Federal Dependencies (Dependencias Federales, a special territory), and Guayana Esequiba (claimed in a border dispute with Guyana). Venezuela is further subdivided into 335 municipalities (municipios); these are subdivided into over one thousand parishes (parroquias).
The easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It borders the Gulf of Thailand, Gulf of Tonkin, and South China Sea, alongside China, Laos, and Cambodia.

A group of islands in the Caribbean that are an insular area of the United States. The islands are geographically part of the Virgin Islands archipelago and are located in the Leeward Islands of the Lesser Antilles. The US Virgin Islands are an organized, unincorporated United States territory. The US Virgin Islands are administratively divided into two districts and subdivided into 20 sub-districts.
A coral atoll (despite its name) having a coastline of 19 km in the North Pacific Ocean, located about two-thirds of the way from Honolulu (3,700 km west) to Guam (2,430 km east).

A Polynesian French island territory (but not part of, or even contiguous with, French Polynesia) in the South Pacific between Fiji and Samoa. It is made up of three main volcanic tropical islands and a number of tiny islets.

A landlocked territory near the Mediterranean coast of Western Asia, bordered by Jordan and the Dead Sea to the east and by Israel to the south, west and north.[2] Under Israeli occupation since 1967, the area is split into 167 Palestinian "islands" under partial Palestinian National Authority civil rule, and 230 Israeli settlements into which Israeli law is "pipelined".

A territory of northwestern Africa, bordered by Morocco to the north, Algeria in the northeast, Mauritania to the east and south, and the Atlantic Ocean on the west. Western Sahara is administratively divided into four regions.

A country located on the Arabian Peninsula in Southwest Asia. Yemen is bordered by Saudi Arabia to the North, the Red Sea to the West, the Arabian Sea and Gulf of Aden to the South, and Oman to the east. Yemen's territory includes over 200 islands, the largest of which is Socotra, about 415 km to the south of Yemen, off the coast of Somalia. As of 2004-02, Yemen is divided into twenty governorates (muhafazah) and one municipality. The population of each governorate is listed in the table below. The governorates of Yemen are divided into 333 districts (muderiah). The districts are subdivided into 2,210 sub-districts, and then into 38,284 villages (as of 2001).

A landlocked country in Southern Africa. The neighbouring countries are the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the north, Tanzania to the north-east, Malawi to the east, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Botswana, and Namibia to the south, and Angola to the west. The capital city is Lusaka. Zambia is divided into nine provinces. Each province is subdivided into several districts with a total of 73 districts.

A landlocked country in the southern part of the continent of Africa, between the Zambezi and Limpopo rivers. It is bordered by South Africa to the south, Botswana to the southwest, Zambia to the northwest, and Mozambique to the east. Zimbabwe is divided into eight provinces and two cities with provincial status. The provinces are subdivided into 59 districts and 1,200 municipalities.
A facility in which non-human animals are slaughtered and processed for human consumption.
A manufactured cage which may be used to confine, contain, or protect an animal.
An aquarium is a vivarium which simulates the submerged portions of an aquatic environment
A wetland ecosystem which is constructed to treat municipal or industrial wastewater, greywater or stormwater runoff.
A permanent walled and roofed construction.
A farm building used for housing livestock, storing machinery or crops etc
A barn where animals are kept for breeding purposes.
A barn where broiler chickens are reared.
A barn where sheep are kept.
A building which encloses one or more self-contained ecosystems or living environments.
A human house which is small and is typically in a rural or semi-rural location.
A dairy is a building in which animal milk is harvested and, optionally, processed for human consumption.
A hospital is a building in which health care services are provided by specialized staff and equipment.
A research facility in which systems of manufactured products control internal conditions and in which scientific or technological research, experiments, and measurement may be performed.
A small-scale outdoor enclosure for raising domestic pigs as livestock.
A part, section, or fixture of a building.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A building part which is a pipe, vent or other device that enables air to be drawn in from outside a building.
An animal enclosure for holding livestock.
A building floor is a surface layer which is part of a building and used for walking.
Building walls are bulding parts which serve to support roofs, floors and ceilings; enclose a space as part of the building envelope; give buildings form; and to provide shelter and security.
A manufactured product which is the surface of a table or cabinet on which work is performed.
A manufactured product which is a flat, long piece of material fastened horizontally, as on a wall or bookcase, to support objects.
Division or compartment for an animal, usually within a house
A building part which is a mainly horizontal surface or ledge at the bottom of a window which provides structural support.
A stream that is usually smaller than a river.
An area of land which is used for the cultivation of crops or grazing of livestock, including any agricultural constructions therein.
A farm where animals are kept for breeding purposes.
A farm where cows are kept for the purpose of producing milk and other dairy products.
A facility in which fish are raised commercially in tanks or enclosures, usually for food.
A farm which is used for conducting agricultural research.

An agricultural facility, working farm, and research centre of the Research Branch of Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada. This farm is centrally located in and completely surrounded by the City of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. The CEF is bordered by the Rideau Canal (a National Historic Site as well) to the east, by Baseline Road to the south, by Merivale and Fisher Roads to the west, and Carling Avenue to the north.
A construction in which eggs are hatched under artificial conditions.
A hatchery in which the eggs of poultry are hatched under artificial conditions
A body of water or other liquid of considerable size contained in a depression on a landmass.
A pit which is used for the collection and storage of manure.
A bounded area of land, or water, usually in its natural or semi-natural (landscaped) state and set aside for some purpose, usually to do with recreation or conservation.
A planned environmental usage process during which an environment supports the sale of goods to ultimate consumers, usually in small quantities.
A building in which a business presents a selection of goods and offers to trade or sell them to customers for money or other goods.
A food shop in which meat, poultry, and sometimes fish are sold.
A shop which sells companion animals to the public.
A food shop in which food products are the primary offer for sale or trade.

A stream which, through permanent or seasonal flow processes, moves from elevated land towards lower elevations through a definite channel and empties either into a sea, lake, or another river or ends on land as bed seepage and evapotranspiration exceed water supply.
A vehicle which is nonautomative and is designed to be hauled by a motorized vehicle.
A truck is a motor vehicle which, as its primary funcion, transports cargo rather than human passangers.
The surface layer of a volume of water.
A facility in which animals are confined within enclosures and displayed to the public, and in which they may also be bred.
A type of weather in which the sky is mostly or completely obscured by clouds
A type of weather in which the sky is partially obscured by clouds
A type of weather in which light rain falls in very fine drops.
A visible mass of cloud water droplets or ice crystals suspended in the air at or near the surface of an astronomical body.
An aggregate of raindrops falling to a planetary surface during a precipitation process.
Snow is an environmental material which is primarily composed of flakes of crystalline water ice.

A storm is an environmental process in which an environmental system and the processes it participates in are strongly perturbed by external forcings. These forcings typically increase the rates of processes unfolding in the system, relative to their normal rates.
A type of weather in which the sun can be seen to shine brightly.
A domesticated junglefowl of the species Gallus gallus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A crop is any cultivated plant, fungus, or alga that is harvested for food, clothing, livestock,fodder, biofuel, medicine, or other uses

Fish are the gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals that lack limbs with digits. Most fish are ectothermic ("cold-blooded"), allowing their body temperatures to vary as ambient temperatures change, though some of the large active swimmers like white shark and tuna can hold a higher core temperature.
A stout-bodied, hooved and short-legged, omnivorous mammal from the species Sus scofus, with thick skin usually sparsely coated with short bristles.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: Domesticated fowl grown for their meat and eggs.
A domesticated, even-toed, ungluate, ruminant mammal typically kept as livestock for its wool and meat, usually of the species Ovis aries.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A fish that is found in aquatic tropical environment.
A large, mainly domesticated game bird characterized by a bald head and wattles (in the male) of the species Meleagris gallopavo.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: The mixture of gases (roughly (by molar content/volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.038% carbon dioxide, trace amounts of other gases, and a variable amount (average around 1%) of water vapor) that surrounds the planet Earth.
An equipment used to feed and water livestock animals.
An animal feeding equipment that has a food storage unit and which enables livestock to obtain their own food.
An animal feeding equipment that has a water storage unit which enables livestock to obtain their own water.
A bowl or pan which is used to feed livestock.
A bowl from which animals can drink.
An equipment used in the transportation of an animal
A type of trailer used to by a dead haul truck to transport dead animal from an abattoir.
A truck used to haul dead animals from an abattoir.
A type of trailer used to by a live haul truck to transport live animals.
A truck used to haul live animals.
A device consisting of a narrow loop of material moving over shafts or pulleys.
A treated form of sludge, sometimes used as a fertilizer in agriculture.
A footwear which covers the foot, the ankle, and sometimes the leg below the knee.
A personal protective device which is an impermiable material which covers a shoe or boot in order to prevent spread of specific environmental contaminants.
A cleaning equipment piece which is a bundle of fibres attached to a long handle, and is used for sweeping.
Contaminated water which eminates from a structure such as a wastewater treatment plant, sewer pipe, or industrial outfall, into the environment.
The box which is used to transport chick (juvenile chicken).
The lining of a box or crate used to transport chicks (juvenile chickens).
An equipment piece used for cleaning a built environment or a manufactured product.
The aerobically decomposed remnants of organic materials.
A type of water that contains contaminants such as pathogens, debris, chemicals, etc.
A mixture of fecal material mixed, buffer, and other materials, that is homogenized and strained and used in fecal microbiota translpantation.
A type of fluid obtained from rinsing meat for the purpose of collecting materials and organisms that are on its surface.
Contaminated water which eminates from a structure such as a wastewater treatment plant, sewer pipe, or industrial outfall, into the environment.

Surface water which is 1) from some rainwater, stormwater, meltwater, or other local source and 2) which can no longer sufficiently rapidly infiltrate into soil, and instead flows along a drainage slope.
A type of water obtained from rinsing poultry carcasses during the feather plucking process.
Water that has been adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence.
A fluid that leaks from a bag containing an animal carcass, and can include water, chemicals and anatomical fluids.
A manufactured product which is a container, traditionally made of wooden slates, designed to protect transported goods from damage.
A manufactured product which is a reusable container that accumulates waste until it is periodically emptied or replaced.
Minute solid particles with diameters less than 500 micrometers. Occurs in and may be deposited from, the atmosphere.
A conveyor belt used to collect eggs in an industrial egg production environment.
A device designed to create an air current through the rotation of a planar surface.
A compartment, room, or device for freezing things or keeping them frozen.
The handle of a freezer door.
Organic matter, mostly animal feces, that is used as organic fertilizer in agriculture.
A type of manure containing solid, semisolid, and liquid by-products generated by animals grown to produce meat, milk, eggs, and other agricultural products for human use and consumption.
Manure which is primarily composed of pig feces.
A part of the plucking machine that moves the birds through the stages of plucking within the plucking apparatus.
A feather lacking a vane and having a rudimentary rachis and a tuft of non-interlocked barbs with elongated barbules extending from the calamus.
A mixture of poultry excreta, spilled feed, feathers, and material used as bedding in poultry operations.

Soil is an environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.
A type of soil used for agriculture that supports the physical, chemical, and biological needs of the desired crop during production.

Sediment is an environmental substance comprised of any particulate matter that can be transported by fluid flow and which eventually is deposited as a layer of solid particles on the bedor bottom of a body of water or other liquid.
A type of liquid that is colorless, transparent, and odorless, that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms.
Underground water which is located in pore spaces found in rock or unconsolidated deposits such as soil, clay, or gravel.
Water that is found on the surface of an astronomical object.
A fluid that is composed of blood plasma and erythrocytes.
Liquid components of living organisms. includes fluids that are excreted or secreted from the body as well as body water that normally is not.
A clear, colorless, bodily fluid, that occupies the subarachnoid space and the ventricular system around and inside the brain and spinal cord.
Amniotic fluid is a bodily fluid consisting of watery liquid surrounding and cushioning a growing fetus within the amnion.
A fluid produced in the oral cavity by salivary glands, typically used in predigestion, but also in other functions.

Multicellular anatomical structure that consists of many cells of one or a few types, arranged in an extracellular matrix such that their long-range organisation is at least partly a repetition of their short-range organisation.
The partially digested food, microbiota, mucus and fluids found in the digestive tract.
The partially digested food, microbiota, mucus and fluids found in the caecum.
The partially digested food, microbiota, mucus and fluids found in the intestine.
The partially digested food and fluids found in the stomach.
Portion of semisolid bodily waste discharged through the anus.
A mixture of feces obtained from multiple individuals.
A dark greenish mass that accumulates in the bowel during fetal life and is discharged shortly after birth.
Excretion that is the output of a kidney.
A body of a multi-cellular organism that is no longer living.
The dead body of a pig.
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs devoted to the ingestion, digestion, and assimilation of food and the discharge of residual wastes.

pouch in the digestive tract that connects the ileum with the ascending colon of the large intestine. It is separated from the ileum by the ileocecal valve, and is the beginning of the large intestine. It is also separated from the colon by the cecocolic junction.
A portion of the large intestine before it becomes the rectum. In mammals, the colon is the most part of the large intestine, excluding the vermiform appendix, the rectum and the anal canal.
An organ that aids digestion and stores bile produced by the liver.
A mucosa that is part of a gastrointestinal system.
The muscular enlargement of the alimentary canal that has usually thick muscular walls and a tough horny lining for grinding the food and when the crop is present follows it and the proventriculus.
Segment of the alimentary canal extending from the stomach to the anus and, in humans and other mammals, consists of two segments, the small intestine and the large intestine.

Subdivision of digestive tract that connects the stomach to the large intestine and is where much of the digestion and absorption of food takes place (with the exception of ruminants). The mammalian small intestine is long and coiled and can be differentiated histologically into: duodenum, jejunem, ileum.

The first part of the small intestine. At the junction of the stomach and the duodenum the alimentary canal is inflected. The duodenum first goes anteriorly for a short distance, turns dorsally, and eventually caudally, thus it is a U-shaped structure with two horizontal sections (a ventral and a dorsal one).
The portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon.
The portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum.
An expanded region of the vertebrate alimentary tract that serves as a food storage compartment and digestive organ. A stomach is lined, in whole or in part by a glandular epithelium.

The fourth stomach of ruminating animals, which is an elongated pear-shaped sac lying on the floor of the abdomen, on the right-hand side, and roughly between the seventh and twelfth ribs. It leads to the beginning of the small intestine.

The first compartment of the ruminant stomach. It lies on the left side of the body, occupying the whole of the left side of the abdomen and even stretching across the median plane of the body to the right side. It is capacious, divided into an upper and a lower sac, each of which has a blind sac at its posterior extremity.
An organ or anatomical structure associated with excretion or detoxification of substances in the body.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: Orifice at the opposite end of an animal's digestive tract from the mouth. Its function is to expel feces, unwanted semi-solid matter produced during digestion, which, depending on the type of animal, may be one or more of: matter which the animal cannot digest, such as bones; food material after all the nutrients have been extracted, for example cellulose or lignin; ingested matter which would be toxic if it remained in the digestive tract; and dead or excess gut bacteria and other endosymbionts.
A type of gland occurring as solitary or in pairs or groups, near the anus and sometimes opening into the rectum.
Common chamber into which the intestines and excretory system opens. Arises during development in all vertebrates, but in many it becomes subdivided, lost or incorporated into other structures.

An exocrine gland which secretes bile and functions in metabolism of protein and carbohydrate and fat, synthesizes substances involved in the clotting of the blood, synthesizes vitamin A, detoxifies poisonous substances, stores glycogen, and breaks down worn-out erythrocytes
A paired organ of the urinary tract which has the production of urine as its primary function.
The terminal portion of the intestinal tube, terminating with the anus.
The organ that functions to filter blood and to store red corpuscles and platelets.
Distensible musculomembranous organ situated in the anterior part of the pelvic cavity in which urine collects before excretion.
The terminal part of the vertebrate leg upon which an individual stands. 2: An invertebrate organ of locomotion or attachment; especially: a ventral muscular surface or process of a mollusk.
The head is the anterior-most division of the body.

The brain is the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate, and most invertebrate, animals. Some primitive animals such as jellyfish and starfish have a decentralized nervous system without a brain, while sponges lack any nervous system at all. In vertebrates, the brain is located in the head, protected by the skull and close to the primary sensory apparatus of vision, hearing, balance, taste, and smell.

Sense organ in vertebrates that is specialized for the detection of sound, and the maintenance of balance. Includes the outer ear and middle ear, which collect and transmit sound waves; and the inner ear, which contains the organs of balance and (except in fish) hearing. Also includes the pinna, the visible part of the outer ear, present in some mammals.
An organ that detects light.

The proximal portion of the digestive tract, containing the oral cavity and bounded by the oral opening. In vertebrates, this extends to the pharynx and includes gums, lips, tongue and parts of the palate. Typically also includes the teeth, except where these occur elsewhere (e.g. pharyngeal jaws) or protrude from the mouth (tusks).
The olfactory organ of vertebrates, consisting of nares, olfactory epithelia and the structures and skeletal framework of the nasal cavity.
A skeletal element of the ethmoid region with complex morphology that are lined with mucuous membranes involved in either olfaction or air conditioning.
The section of the pharynx that lies above the soft palate.
Pair of nostrils.
The paired air-filled cavities surrounded by the bones of the face that are lined by mucous membranes and are continuous with the nasal cavity.
The projecting nose and mouth of an animal, especially a mammal.

An organ system subdivision that is a network of vessels capable of removing accumulating protein and fluid from the interstitial space and returning it to the vascular space. In some species, this network is connected to the immune system via lymph nodes and lymphocyte-producing organs, with the whole being the lymphoid system.

Any of the rounded masses of lymphoid tissue that are surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue, are distributed along the lymphatic vessels, and contain numerous lymphocytes which filter the flow of lymph.
The lymph nodes located in the mesentery, of which there are 3 classes: ileocolic, juxtaintestinal mesenteric, and central superior group.
An organism subdivision that extends from the head to the pectoral girdle, encompassing the cervical vertebral column.

Tube that connects the pharynx to the stomach. In mammals, the oesophagus connects the buccal cavity with the stomach. The stratified squamous non-keratinised epithelium lining the buccal cavity is continued through the pharynx down into the oesophagus. The lowest part of the oesophagus (ca. 2 cm) is lined with gastric mucosa and covered by peritoneum. The main body of the oesophagus is lined with small, simple mucous glands. Each gland opens into the lumen by a long duct which pierces the muscularis mucosae (Wilson and Washington, 1989). A sphincter is situated at the point where the oesophagus enters the stomach to prevent gastro-oesophageal reflux, i.e. to prevent acidic gastric contents from reaching stratified epithelia of the oesophagus, where they can cause inflammation and irritation.
The trachea is the portion of the airway that attaches to the bronchi as it branches.

An enclosed, cable-like bundle of axons in the peripheral nervous system originating in a nerve root in the central nervous system (or a condensed nervous structure) connecting with peripheral structures.

Part of the central nervous system located in the vertebral canal continuous with and caudal to the brain; demarcated from brain by plane of foramen magnum. It is composed of an inner core of gray matter in which nerve cells predominate, and an outer layer of white matter in which myelinated nerve fibers predominate, and surrounds the central canal.
An object aggregate which has as members whole organs or parts of organs, possibly from different organisms.
Anatomical structure that performs a specific function or group of functions
Organ consisting of a tissue made up of various elongated cells that are specialized to contract and thus to produce movement and mechanical work.
The organ covering the body that consists of the dermis and epidermis.
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs concerned with reproduction.

Anatomical entity that comprises the organism in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems. For example, for mammals, the process would begin with zygote formation and end with birth. For insects, the process would begin at zygote formation and end with larval hatching. For plant zygotic embryos, this would be from zygote formation to the end of seed dormancy. For plant vegetative embryos, this would be from the initial determination of the cell or group of cells to form an embryo until the point when the embryo becomes independent of the parent plant.
An embryo that is at the late embryonic stage; this stage covers late steps of the embryogenesis with a fully formed embryo still developing before birth or egg hatching
The gonad of a female organism which contains germ cells.
A tube or collection of tubes in an animal from the ovaries to the outside of the body.

Organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother, partly of embryonic origin and partly of maternal origin[GO]. The fetal portion of the placenta is known as the villous chorion. The maternal portion is known as the decidua basalis. The two portions are held together by anchoring villi that are anchored to the decidua basalis by the cytotrophoblastic shell.
A gonad of a male animal. A gonad produces and releases sperm.
The female muscular organ of gestation in which the developing embryo or fetus is nourished until birth.
A fibromuscular tubular tract leading from the uterus to the exterior of the body in female placental mammals and marsupials, or to the cloaca in female birds, monotremes, and some reptiles

A sac-like expansion of the ventral wall of the intestine, narrowed into a yolk stalk near the body[Hyman's]. Membranous sac attached to an embryo, providing early nourishment in the form of yolk in bony fishes, sharks, reptiles, birds, and primitive mammals. It functions as the developmental circulatory system of the human embryo, before internal circulation begins. In the mouse, the yolk sac is the first site of blood formation, generating primitive macrophages and erythrocytes.
Functional system which consists of structures involved in respiration.
Any of the membranous air-filled extensions of the lungs of birds, which increase the efficiency of gaseous exchange in the lungs.
Respiration organ that develops as an outpocketing of the esophagus
The invaginated serous membrane that surrounds the lungs (the visceral portion) and lines the walls of the pleural cavity (parietal portion).
The mucous membrane lining the respiratory tract.
Anatomical system that is a multi-element, multi-tissue anatomical cluster that consists of the skeleton and the articular system.
Anatomical cluster that consists of two or more adjacent skeletal structures, which may be interconnected by various types of tissue.
Skeletal element that is composed of bone tissue.
Subdivision of trunk that lies between the head and the abdomen.

The subdivision of the vertebrate body between the thorax and pelvis. The ventral part of the abdomen contains the abdominal cavity and visceral organs. The dorsal part includes the abdominal section of the vertebral column.
Muscle (organ) which is a part of the abdomen. Examples: external oblique, rectus abdominis.
Muscle (organ) which is a part of the abdomen. Examples: external oblique, rectus abdominis.
Anatomical system that consists of all blood and lymph vessels.
A vessel through which blood circulates in the body.

An epithelial and lymphoid organ that develops as a dorsal diverticulum of the proctodeal region of the cloaca in birds. The luminal (interior) surface of the bursa is plicated with as many as 15 primary and 7 secondary plicae or folds. These plicae have hundreds of bursal follicles containing follicle-associated epithelial cells, lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells. Lymphoid stem cells migrate from the fetal liver to the bursa during ontogeny. In the bursa, these stem cells acquire the characteristics of mature, immunocompetent B cells. The bursa is an organ found in birds involved in B cell differentiation.
A myogenic muscular circulatory organ found in the vertebrate cardiovascular system composed of chambers of cardiac muscle. It is the primary circulatory organ.
Respiration organ that develops as an outpocketing of the esophagus
The combination of pericardial sac (a double-walled sac containing the heart and the roots of the great vessels) plus fibrous pericardium.
Food material which can be used to meet nutritional requirements of animals, particularly livestock such as cattle, goats, sheep, horses, chickens and pigs.
Blood meal is a dry, inert powder made from blood used as a high-nitrogen organic fertilizer and a high protein animal feed.
A mixture of crushed and coarsely ground bones that is used as an organic fertilizer for plants and formerly in animal feed.
The co-product produced after the extraction of oil from Brassica carinata plant.
Canola meal is an oilseed meal made from canola grain. Canola meal is a by-product of the oil crushing process.
A type of animal feed in which various concentrated feed ingredients are premixed with different vitamins, minerals, trace elements and other feed additives.
A type of compound feed premix in which medicinal substances have been added.
A by product of processing poultry which is made from poultry feathers by partially grinding them under elevated heat and pressure, and then grinding and drying.

Fish meal is primarily used as a protein supplement in compound feed. As of 2010, about 56% of fish meal was used to feed farmed fish, about 20% was used in pig feed, about 12% in poultry feed, and about 12% in other uses, which included fertilizer.
Food formulated for the laying hens to increase egg production and egg shell quality.

Meat and bone meal (MBM) is a product of the rendering industry. It is typically about 48–52% protein, 33–35% ash, 8–12% fat, and 4–7% water. It is primarily used in the formulation of animal feed to improve the amino acid profile of the feed.
A meal that is obtained by cooking, defatting, sterilizing, grinding, and sifting by-products of an animal.
Pet food is plant or animal material intended for consumption by pets.

A type of ground protein-rich residue from the production of soybean oil used chiefly in animal feeds, in adhesives and plastics, in making synthetic protein fibers, and in fermentation media (as for the production of antibiotics).
An ingredient used to prepare animal feed.
A dairy food product has mammilian milk or a milk component as an ingredient.
A whole cheese block or some substance made from a block of processed cheese.
Milk powder that is obtained by removing all of the water from pasteurized skim milk.
An emulsion of fat globules within a fluid that is secreted by the mammary gland during lactation.
Index dietary/food supplements according to legal and market definitions.
Poultry, game bird or turtle eggs.
A fertilized developing egg embryo that is boiled and eaten from the shell.
The yellow spheroidal mass of stored food that forms the inner portion of the egg of a bird or reptile and is surrounded by the white.
A food product consisting mainly of poultry eggs or derivatives.
An egg produced by a chicken hen.
A whole egg with a shell from poultry.
A mixture of two or more separate food components
A type of food substance used as a replacement for another type of food that looks and behaves similarly e.g. imitation crab meant, almond milk.
A type of food substance used to replace cow's milk that looks and behaves similarly e.g. almond milk.
A meat product is a product organized by the form of - or processing done to - its meat component (a skeletal meat part of an animal or crustacean).
A portion of sliced meat breaded and served either grilled or fried.
A narrow strip or slice of boneless meat or fish especially e.g. the tenderloin of beef.
A whole raw liver is a whole liver organ obtained from an animal during a butchery process.
The pieces of meat remaining after steaks, roasts, and other cuts are removed.
The joined section of meat and bone cut from the ribs of an animal.
A cut of meat that comes from the rib section of an animal.
A boneless cut of meat from the area where the clod meets the edge of the pectoral muscle in an animal.

Term: Grains, cereals, and bakery product (organizational term)
Definition: A food product consisting of grains and/or cereals.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A whole bread loaf or some substance made from a loaf of processed bread.
A mixture of processed cereal grains often consumed with dairy products such as milk.
A large quantity of grain without any retail packaging.
A one-celled fruit (pod) usually dehiscing down both sutures, and having the seed attached along a ventral suture.
A seed of a chickpea plant (Cicer arietinum).
Hummus is a Levantine dip or spread made from cooked, mashed chickpeas or other beans, blended with tahini, olive oil, lemon juice, salt, and garlic.
A whole soybean or some substance made from a processed soybean.
A food product that consists of some meat, poultry or fish.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A ground beef product is made of beef that has been finely chopped with a knife or a meat grinder (American English) or mincing machine (British English). Ground beef is used in many recipes including hamburgers and spaghetti Bolognese.
Ground or minced beef that has had no bone material in it.
A food product made of extra-lean, ground or minced beef.
A food product made of lean, ground or minced beef.
A food product made of medium, ground or minced beef.
A food product made of regular, ground or minced beef.
Ground or minced beef that comes from the sirloin region.

A hamburger (short: burger) is a sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun. The patty may be pan fried, grilled, or flame broiled.
The primal cut of beef taken from the shoulder region.
Meat chop from the shoulder region of beef.
Meat chop from the sirloin region of beef
A chunk of beef used as an ingredient in making stew.
A cut of beef corresponding to the psoas major muscle, which is very tender.
A whole cut of beef or some substance made from processed beef.
A meat cut from the breast of an animal, typically a cow.
Chicken breast consists mainly of the breast meat portion of a chicken, and may or may not include connected bone (boneless versus "with bone") and skin.
A chicken breast with its backbone removed.
A chicken breast after the skin has been removed.
A chicken breast that still contains the skin.
A chicken breast after the skin and bones have been removed.
A cutlet made from chicken breast.
A segment of a chicken's leg between the thigh and tarsus (ankle).
A chicken drumstick after the skin has been removed.
A chicken drumstick that still contains the skin.
Meat from a chicken
A food product made of ground or minced chicken meat.
A food product made of lean, ground or minced chicken meat.

Term: Chicken meat (ground or minced, extra lean)
Definition: A food product made of extra lean, ground or minced chicken meat.
A food product made of medium, ground or minced chicken meat.
A food product made of regular, ground or minced chicken meat.
Ground or minced chicken meat that has had no bone material in it.
A chicken nugget is a chicken product made from chicken meat that is breaded or battered, then deep-fried or baked.
The butchery thigh cut of a chicken
A chicken thigh after the skin has been removed.
A chicken thigh that has had skin and bone material removed.
A chicken thigh that still contains the skin.
Meat from the upper thigh of a chicken.
Chicken's upper thigh that contains the skin.
The wing of a chicken
A fish food product includes products made from any fish species (aquatic vertebrate with gills and fins).
A fish steak, alternatively known as a fish cutlet, is a cut of fish which is cut perpendicular to the spine and can either include the bones or be boneless.

Ham is pork from a leg cut that has been preserved by wet or dry curing, with or without smoking. As a processed meat, the term "ham" includes both whole cuts of meat and ones that have been mechanically formed.

Head cheese is a cold cut that originated in Europe. Head cheese is not a dairy cheese, but a terrine or meat jelly made with flesh from the head of a calf or pig, or less commonly a sheep or cow, and often set in aspic. A version pickled with vinegar is known as souse.
A by-product of meat-packing which consists of bits and trimmings of meat freed from fat, that is dehydrated and reduced to a meal used as a rich source of protein in animal rations.
A cut of meat which is long, narrow and boneless.
The meat of an adult sheep is mutton, a term only used for the meat, not the living animals.
A cut of meat (a meat chop) cut perpendicularly to the spine of the pig and usually containing a rib or part of a vertebra, served as an individual portion.
Meat from a pig that has been ground or minced.
Ground or minced pork meat that has had no bone material in it.

Term: Pork meat (ground or minced, extra lean)
Definition: A food product made of extra-lean, ground or minced pork meat.
A food product made of lean, ground or minced pork meat.
A food product made of medium, ground or minced pork meat.
A food product made of regular, ground or minced pork meat.
Ground or minced pork meat that comes from the sirloin region.
The primal cut from a pig’s shoulder, above the forelegs.
Meat chop from the blade roast of pork.
Pork chop from the sirloin region.
Pork steaks are steaks cut from the shoulder of the pig.
A cut of pork corresponding to the psoas major muscle which is very tender.
Any meat from one or more poultry birds.
The leg cut of a poultry bird.
The calf part of a poultry hindleg (hindlimb zeugopod)
The neck cut of a poultry bird.
The thigh cut of a poultry bird.
The wing cut of a poultry bird.
A type of minced and seasoned meat that has been encased in a skin in the shape of a cylinder and cooked or preserved.
A highly seasoned beef and or pork sausage.
A cured sausage consisting of fermented and air-dried meat, typically pork.

The term shellfish is used both broadly and specifically. For regulatory purposes it is often narrowly defined as filter-feeding molluscs such as clams, mussels, and oyster to the exclusion of crustaceans and all else. Although their shells may differ, all shellfish are invertebrates.
Turkey breast consists mainly of the breast meat portion of a turkey, and may or may not include connected bone ("deboned or boneless versus bone-in") and skin.
A turkey breast with its backbone removed.
A turkey breast after the skin has been removed.
A turkey breast that has had skin and bone material removed.
A turkey breast that still contains the skin.
Meat from the lower joint of the leg of a turkey.
A turkey drumstick after the skin has been removed.
A turkey drumstick that still contains the skin.
A turkey meat food product is any food product made predominantly of turkey parts.
A food product made of ground or minced turkey meat.
A food product made of lean, ground or minced turkey meat.

Term: Turkey meat (ground or minced, extra lean)
Definition: A food product made of extra-lean, ground or minced turkey meat.
A food product made of medium, ground or minced turkey meat.
A food product made of regular, ground or minced turkey meat.
Ground or minced turkey meat that has had no bone material in it.
A thigh poultry cut of turkey.
A turkey thigh after the skin has been removed.
A turkey thigh that has had skin and bone material removed.
A turkey thigh that still contains the skin.
Meat from the upper thigh of a turkey.
Turkey's upper thigh that contains the skin.
The wing of a turkey.

Veal is the meat of calves, in contrast to the beef from older cattle. Veal can be produced from a calf of either sex and any breed; however, most veal comes from young males of dairy breeds which are not used for breeding.
Meat of a calf that is raised on a fortified milk formula diet and solid feed.
Meat from a calf that is raised on grain, hay, or other solid food, in addition to milk
A food product derived from one or more microorganisms including bacteria, mold, and yeast.
Yeasts are eukaryotic micro-organisms classified in the kingdom *Fungi*, with 1,500 species currently described estimated to be only 1% of all fungal species.
A food product derived from nuts and seeds, either whole or in parts.
A whole almond or some substance made from a processed almond.
A drupe fruit of an almond plant (Prunus dulcis).
A powder made from chia seeds.
A whole chia seed or some substance made from a processed chia seed.
A powder that is prepared by grinding flax seeds.

The hazelnut is the nut of the hazel and therefore includes any of the nuts deriving from species of the genus Corylus, especially the nuts of the species Corylus avellana. It also is known as cobnut or filbert nut according to species.
A dry fruit consisting of an edible kernel enclosed in a woody or leathery shell.
A paste of ground roasted peanuts, usually eaten spread on bread.
The edible seed of the sesame plant.
A condiment made from toasted ground hulled sesame.
The edible seed of the walnut plant.

Food product that is 1) ready or nearly ready for consumption; 2) usually a composite of several foods or ingredients that often belong to distinct product types; 3) usually formulated, mixed and partially or fully cooked.
A substance such as a sauce or powder that is used to add flavor to food e.g. ketchup.
Food items that are rich in sugar, any one or type of which is called a confection. Modern usage may include substances rich in artificial sweeteners as well.
A snack is a small portion of food and generally eaten between meals.
A type of farm-produced crop or crops, usually fruits and vegetables, which are fresh and generally in the same state as where and when they were harvested.
An apple, whole or in pieces, for eating, baking or other food processing.
A pome fruit of an apple tree (Malus domestica).
Arugula, (Eruca sativa) is an edible annual plant, also known as rocket salad, rucola, rucoli, rugula, colewort, and roquette.
A whole cantaloupe or some substance made from a processed cantaloupe.
The chili pepper is the fruit of plants from the genus Capsicum which are members of the nightshade family, Solanaceae.
A whole coconut or some substance made from a processed coconut.
A cooked ear of sweet corn (maize) eaten directly off the cob, and or the kernels obtained from the cob.
A whole cucumber or some substance made from a processed cucumber.
A multi-tissue plant structure (PO:0025496) that develops from a gynoecium (PO:0009062), or a single carpel (PO:0009030), and at maturity may have as parts one or more seeds
Raw plant leaves eaten as a vegetable, sometimes accompanied by tender petioles and shoots.
A whole kale leaf or some substance made from a processed kale leaf.
A whole lettuce head or some substance made from a processed lettuce head.
A whole mango or some substance made from a processed mango.
A fruitbody of a mushroom.
Whole papaya or some substance made from processed papaya.
A whole pattypan squash or some substance made from a processed pattypan squash.
A whole pepper or some substance made from processed pepper.
A cold dish of various mixtures of raw or cooked vegetables, usually seasoned with oil, vinegar, or other dressing and sometimes accompanied by meat, fish, or other ingredients.
A whole scallion or some substance made from a processed scallion.
Whole spinach or some substance made from processed spinach.
A young plant growing from a seed; may have small leaves. The endosperm is diminished or removed.
A seed which has germinated and put out shoots.
A sprout from an alfalfa seed.
A bean sprout is a germinated bean to be eaten raw or cooked
A sprouted chia seed.
A food product made from more than one sprouted seed.
A germinated or sprouted seed of a mung bean plant (Vigna radiata).
A whole tomato or some substance made from a processed tomato.
A whole vegetable or some substance made from a processed vegetable.
A vegetable product such as leaves, flowers, seeds and roots that is rich in essential oils and aromatic principles. Used mainly a a condiment.
Whole basil or some substance made from processed basil.
A whole black pepper or some substance made from processed black pepper.
A whole cardamom or some substance made from a processed cardamom.
A whole chive leaf or some substance made from a processed chive leaf.
A powder that is prepared by grinding coriander seeds.
A whole coriander seed or some substance made from a processed coriander seed.
A powder that is prepared by grinding cumin seeds.
A seed of a cumin plant (Cuminum cyminum).
Whole black cumin seed or some substance made from a processed black cumin seed.
A whole curry leaf or some substance made from a processed curry leaf.
A mixture of finely ground spices, such as turmeric, ginger, and coriander, used for making curry.
The aromatic foliage and seeds of dill (usually Anethum graveolens) which are used in flavoring foods and especially pickles.
Whole fennel or some substance made from processed fennel.
A spice derived from grounding dehydrated garlic into a powder.
A whole ginger root or some substance made from a processed ginger root.
A whole mint leaf or some substance made from a processed mint leaf.
A whole oregano leaf or some substance made from a processed oregano leaf.
A powdered spice with a deep orange-red color and a mildly pungent flavor, made from the dried and ground fruits of certain varieties of pepper.
A whole parsley leaf or some substance made from a processed parsley leaf.
A spice derived from grounding dried peppercorns usually obtained from the flowering vine of the species Piper nigrum.
A traditional south Indian condiment made with roasted lentils, whole spices and fresh herbs.
A leaf of a sage plant (Salvia officinalis).
A spice that is bright yellow in colour spice that is made by grounding the dried root of the ginger plant Curcuma longa.
An aromatic or pungent vegetable substance used to flavor food, e.g. cloves, pepper, or cumin.
A whole white peppercorn or some substance made from a processed white peppercorn.
A food state quality in which the food has undergone a process of being cut into smaller pieces, chunks or slices.
Food material chopped into roughly bite-sized pieces.
Solid food that is divided into uniformly box-shaped pieces with all sides equal.
A food material that has not been cooked.
A food product which does not have any seasoning applied to it.
A food preparation quality in which a food is seasoned, shaped, or cooked in a similar manner to recipes associated with the Italian cooking style.

USA: The 1990 Farm Act specifies that a food labeled 'organic' must meet four requirements: 1) the food must be raised by specified methods to replenish and maintain the fertility of the soil; 2) the food must be certified as having been produced with a nationally approved list of materials and practices; 3) to be eligible for certification at least three years must have elapsed between the first organic harvest and first use of nationally approved materials on land and crops;and 4) organic foods must meet all local, state and federal regulations governing the quality and safety of the food supply. Europe: Foods produced in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 834/2007 of 28 June 2007 on organic production and labelling of organic products and repealing Regulation (EEC) No 2092/91. [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2007:189:0001:0023:EN:PDF]
Ready-to-serve (or ready-to-eat, RTE) foods are foods not requiring any further preparation before consumption, except perhaps washing/rinsing, thawing or warming.
A hardness quality of giving little resistance to pressure.
A large, domesticated, cloven-hooved, herbivore of the species Bos taurus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: Fish are the gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals that lack limbs with digits. Most fish are ectothermic ("cold-blooded"), allowing their body temperatures to vary as ambient temperatures change, though some of the large active swimmers like white shark and tuna can hold a higher core temperature.
A stout-bodied, hooved and short-legged, omnivorous mammal from the species Sus scofus, with thick skin usually sparsely coated with short bristles.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: Domesticated birds kept by humans for their eggs, their meat or their feathers.
A domesticated junglefowl of the species Gallus gallus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A large, mainly domesticated game bird characterized by a bald head and wattles (in the male) of the species Meleagris gallopavo.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A domesticated, even-toed, ungluate, ruminant mammal typically kept as livestock for its wool and meat, usually of the species Ovis aries.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A device that can be used to restrict the location of material entities over time.
A sac or pouch.
A sterilized sampling bag that is puncture proof tabs for protection from damage due to wire-end protrusion and leak-proof closures.
A rigid or semirigid container typically of glass or plastic having a comparatively narrow neck or mouth and usually no handle.
A container made from solid material and primarily used for holding liquid.
A low flat-bottomed laboratory container for growing a layer of organisms such as bacteria, molds, and cells on a thin layer of nutrient medium e.g. Petri dish, multi-well plate.
A shallow dish with a lid used to culture cells.
A sample collection device consisting of a soft flexible, absorbent pad usually made from natural material such as gauze or cotton, used to absorb specimen fluid or particulate matter.
A device which is a soft, absorbent material mounted on one or both ends of a stick.
A specimen collection device consisting of a specimen pad made of sterile gauze which is aseptically attached to a pole by clips or to a string
A sample collection device consisting of a thin, less absorbent sheet, used to collect material from surfaces.
Any hollow cylindrical anatomical structure containing a lumen through which substances are transported.
A device that collects materials through the process of vacuum suction.

A test tube which is either a sterile glass or plastic tube with a closure that is evacuated to create a vacuum inside the tube facilitating the draw of a predetermined volume of liquid. Most commonly used to draw a blood sample directly from the vein, these also are used to collect urine samples. Vacutainer tube may contain additives designed to stabilize and preserve the specimen prior to analytical testing.
A filtration process which removes solid particulates from the air via an air filtration device.
Inspiration of a foreign object into the airway.
A specimen collection that obtains a sample of tissue or cell from a living multicellular organism body for diagnostic purposes by means intended to be minimally invasive.
A fecal specimen collection method in which feces is obtained by inserting the collection device into the anus of the host, or the feces is captured as it is excreted.
A protocol application to separate cells and/or cellular secretions from an anatomical space by the introduction and removal of fluid
The collection of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL) from the lungs.
The administration and evacuation of small volumes of liquid through an orogastric tube to remove toxic substances within the stomach.
A postmortem examination of the body of an animal to determine the cause of death or the character and extent of changes produced by disease.
The collection of blood from a vein, most commonly via needle venipuncture.
The process of removal and collection of specimen material from the surface of an entity by washing, or a similar application of fluids.
According to FSTA Thesaurus Packaging 3.1 package types, includes boil-in bag, carrier bag, flat bag, inner bag, retort pouch, shipping bag, valve bag, and valve sack
A soft-sided receptacle used as a bag made of paper.
A thin, transparent plastic film that adheres to surfaces and to itself, used to wrap objects and materials in an air-tight manner.
A covering, or wrapper, made of plastic.
A rigid or semirigid container typically of glass or plastic usually having no handle.
A container for the distribution or storage of goods, made of thin metal.
A container made of paper that has been treated with an antimicrobial agent or preservative chemical.
A container made of paper that has not been treated with any agents.
A flat container with raised edges made of plastic used to carry things.
A domesticated junglefowl of the species Gallus gallus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: An animal that is kept as a companion.
A large, domesticated, cloven-hooved, herbivore of the species Bos taurus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: Fish are the gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals that lack limbs with digits. Most fish are ectothermic ("cold-blooded"), allowing their body temperatures to vary as ambient temperatures change, though some of the large active swimmers like white shark and tuna can hold a higher core temperature.
A bipedal primate mammal of the species Homo sapiens.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A stout-bodied, hooved and short-legged, omnivorous mammal from the species Sus scofus, with thick skin usually sparsely coated with short bristles.

Definition: A domesticated, even-toed, ungluate, ruminant mammal typically kept as livestock for its wool and meat, usually of the species Ovis aries.

Definition: A large, mainly domesticated game bird characterized by a bald head and wattles (in the male) of the species Meleagris gallopavo.

Definition: A large, domesticated, cloven-hooved, herbivore raised for its milk, meat and hide.

Definition: A domesticated junglefowl raised for its eggs, feathers and meat.

Definition: A type of primate characterized by bipedalism and large, complex brain.

Definition: A large, mainly domesticated game bird characterized by a bald head and wattles (in the male).
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A domesticated, even-toed, ungluate, ruminant mammal typically kept as livestock for its wool and meat.

Definition: A stout-bodied, hooved and short-legged, omnivorous mammal, with thick skin usually sparsely coated with short bristles raised for its meat.

Definition: Types of Cow as determined by age or stage of production.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: Calves are the young of domestic cattle. Calves are reared to become adult cattle, or are slaughtered for their meat, called veal.
A young cow mature enough either to undergo backgrounding or to be fattened in preparation for slaughter.
A type of cow undergoing a final fattening process prior to sale or slaughter.
A type of cow bred specifically for milk production.
A type of cow that has been weaned and is being fed in a way to add physical bulk to its body.
A type of young cow that has been weaned and consumes solid food.
Types of Cow as determined by sex or stage of reproduction.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A cattle bull is an adult "intact" (i.e. not castrated) male of a cattle species.
A large, domesticated, cloven-hooved, herbivore of the species Bos taurus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: A cow that is genetically female, but has many characteristics of a male and is usually infertile.
A heifer is a young female, under three years of age, of a cattle species before she has had a calf of her own.
A cattle steer is an adult castrated male of a cattle species.
Types of Pig as determined by age or stage of production.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A grower pig over 70 kg (150 lb) liveweight.
A pig between weaning and sale or transfer to the breeding herd, sold for slaughter or killed for rations.
A lactating sow that feeds piglets farrowed by another pig.
A stout-bodied, hooved and short-legged, omnivorous mammal from the species Sus scofus, with thick skin usually sparsely coated with short bristles.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: An unweaned or immature pig.
A young pig recently separated from the sow
Types of Pig as determined by sex or stage of reproduction.
Guidance: This term is not ontologically supported and is present to better structure the pick list.

Definition: A male swine castrated before sexual maturity.
An adult male swine.
A female pig under the age of 1 year. The term is also often used to refer to a pig who has not farrowed, or given birth to a litter.
An adult female swine.
Domesticated birds kept by humans for their eggs, their meat or their feathers.
A chicken younger than 10 weeks old (previously younger than 13 weeks), of either sex, that is tender-meated with soft, pliable, smooth-textured skin and flexible breastbone cartilage.
A surgically neutered male chicken younger than four months old (previously younger than eight months) that is tender-meated with soft, pliable, smooth-textured skin.
A young offspring of any bird.
A domesticated junglefowl of the species Gallus gallus.
Guidance: Note: this definition is specification-specific and is not provided by NCBITaxon.

Definition: The hard-shelled reproductive body produced by a bird (especially by the common domestic chicken) or a reptile; also: its contents used as food.
A young animal that has recently emerged from its egg.
An adult female chicken.
A type of chicken kept for laying eggs.
A type of turkey kept for laying eggs.
A poult is a young domestic chicken, turkey, pheasant, or other fowl being raised for food.
A young hen, especially one less than one year old.
A mature male chicken with coarse skin, toughened and darkened meat, and hardened breastbone tip.
A mature male turkey, usually two years old or more.
A large, mainly domesticated game bird characterized by a bald head and wattles (in the male) of the species Meleagris gallopavo.

Definition: A domesticated, even-toed, ungluate, ruminant mammal typically kept as livestock for its wool and meat, usually of the species Ovis aries.

Definition: An adult male sheep kept for breeding and for wool production.
A castrated male sheep.
A ewe is a female sheep.
In general, a sheep in its first year is called a lamb and its meat is also called lamb.

Fish are the gill-bearing aquatic craniate animals that lack limbs with digits. Most fish are ectothermic ("cold-blooded"), allowing their body temperatures to vary as ambient temperatures change, though some of the large active swimmers like white shark and tuna can hold a higher core temperature.
The eggs or spawn of a fish, contained within or separated from the ovary.
A recently hatched fish that has reached the stage where its yolk-sac has almost disappeared and its swim bladder is operational to the point where the fish can actively feed for itself.
A fish that has not reached sexual maturity.
